# The Circle

\vspace{-12cm}
\begin{center}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[white] (10,5) circle (0.01);
\draw[MidnightBlue,rounded corners,very thick] (1,0.2) rectangle (5,1.8);
\draw[MidnightBlue,very thick] (5,1) -- (6,1);
\draw[MidnightBlue,fill=MidnightBlue,rounded corners] (6,1.8) rectangle (18.2,0.2);
\node[white] at (12.1,1) {\Huge{\textsc{The Circle}}};
\node at (3,1) {\Large{\textsc{Chapter 13}}};
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

The circle a fundamental mathematical shape, and in this chapter its equation will be introduced.

For all points $(x,y)$ on a circle, the distance to the *centre* is the same, and that distance is the *radius*.

\begin{center}
    \begin{tikzpicture}
        \draw[thick] (0,0) circle (2cm);
        \draw[MidnightBlue,fill,thick] (0,0) circle (0.03) node[below] {$\color{black}\text{centre}$} -- (30:2) circle (0.03) node[pos=1.3] {$\color{black}(x,y)$};
        \node[MidnightBlue,rotate=30,above] at (30:1) {radius};
    \end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

In order to fully define a circle lying on an $x$-$y$ Cartesian plane, only two properties are required:

\begin{itemize}
    \item The \textcolor{MidnightBlue}{\textbf{radius}} of the circle.
    \item The \textcolor{MidnightBlue}{\textbf{centre}} of the circle.
\end{itemize}

For any point $(x,y)$ on a circle with \textcolor{MidnightBlue}{\textbf{radius}} $\color{MidnightBlue}r$ and \textcolor{MidnightBlue}{\textbf{centre}} $\color{MidnightBlue}(a,b)$, a right-angle triangle can be constructed:

\begin{center}
    \begin{tikzpicture}[scale=1.2]
        \draw[thick] (0,0) circle (2cm);
        \draw[MidnightBlue,fill,thick] (0,0) circle (0.03) -- (30:2) circle (0.03) node[pos=1.25] {$\color{black}(x,y)$} node[pos=-0.25] {$\color{black}(a,b)$};
        \node[MidnightBlue,rotate=30,above] at (30:1) {$r$};
        \draw (30:2) -- ++(0,-1) -- (0,0);
        \draw (30:2) -- ++(0,-0.9) -- ++(-0.1,0) -- ++(0,-0.1);
        \draw[very thick,-stealth,MidnightBlue] (4,0) -- (5,0);
        \draw (7,-1) -- ++(30:4) -- ++(0,-2) -- (7,-1);
        \draw (7,-1) -- ++(30:4) -- ++(0,-1.8) -- ++(-0.2,0) -- ++(0,-0.2);
        \draw[thick,MidnightBlue] (7,-1) -- ++(30:4) node[pos=0.5,rotate=30,above] {$r$};
        \node[right] at (10.5,0) {$y-b$};
        \node[below] at (8.75,-1) {$x-a$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

By Pythagoras' Theorem, the set of points $(x,y)$ which lie on the circle satisfy the relationship:

\[\color{MidnightBlue}(x-a)^2+(y-b)^2=r^2\]

This is known as the \textcolor{MidnightBlue}{\textbf{equation of the circle}}.

\pagebreak

## The Equation of the Circle

\vspace{-0.5cm}

The equation of the circle, introduced on the previous page, is given in the formula list:

\vspace{-0.3cm}

\begin{center}
\begin{tcolorbox}[colback=red!5,colframe=red!70!black]
\centering
\textbf{The Equation of the Circle} \textit{(as provided on the formula sheet)}:
\begin{equation*}
    \text{The circle with centre }(a,b)\text{ and radius }r\text{ has equation: }
    (x-a)^2+(y-b)^2=r^2
\end{equation*}

\end{tcolorbox}
\end{center}

\vspace{-0.3cm}

When stating the equation of a circle, it is not necessary to expand the brackets unless specified.

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example,colback=MidnightBlue!1, colframe=MidnightBlue]

State the equation of the circle with centre $(5,-2)$ and diameter $6\sqrt{2}$.

\tcblower

\vspace{-0.5cm}

\begin{align*}
   &\text{Centre }=(5,-2)&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{State centre }(a,b)\\[0.5em]
    &\text{Radius }=3\sqrt{2}&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{State radius }r\\[0.5em]
    &\text{Equation: }(x-5)^2+\left(y-(-2)\right)^2=\left(3\sqrt{2}\right)^2&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Substitute into equation}\\[0.5em]
    &\hspace{2.5cm}(x-5)^2+(y+2)^2=18&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Simplify}
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}

The radius and centre of a circle may be quickly stated given its equation:

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example,colback=MidnightBlue!1, colframe=MidnightBlue,height=3.9cm]

State the radius and centre of the circle with equation $(x+4)^2+(y-1)^2=25$.

\tcblower

\vspace{-0.5cm}

\begin{align*}
   &\text{Centre }=(-4,1)&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{State centre }(a,b)\\[0.5em]
    &\text{Radius }=5&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{State radius }r\\[0.5em]
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}

Knowledge from the earlier chapters such as *Straight Lines* and *Vectors* may be required, such as:

\begin{multicols}{2}

\begin{center}
\begin{tcolorbox}[colback=red!5,colframe=red!70!black,height=3.3cm]
\centering
\textbf{The Distance Formula}:
\begin{equation*}
    \text{The distance between }(x_1,y_1)\text{ and  }(x_2,y_2)\text{: }
\end{equation*}
\begin{equation*}
    \textbf{distance}=\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2}
\end{equation*}
\end{tcolorbox}
\end{center}

\begin{center}
\begin{tcolorbox}[colback=red!5,colframe=red!70!black,height=3.3cm]
\centering
\textbf{The Midpoint Formula}:
\begin{equation*}
    \text{The midpoint between }(x_1,y_1)\text{ and  }(x_2,y_2)\text{: }
\end{equation*}
\begin{equation*}
    \textbf{midpoint}=\left(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2},\frac{y_1+y_2}{2}\right)
\end{equation*}
\end{tcolorbox}
\end{center}

\end{multicols}

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example,colback=MidnightBlue!1, colframe=MidnightBlue]

Find the equation of the circle with line PQ as its diameter, where P$(-1,2)$ and Q$(7,-4)$.

\tcblower

\vspace{-0.5cm}

\begin{align*}
   \text{Centre }&=\left(\frac{-1+7}{2},\frac{2+(-4)}{2}\right)=(3,-1)&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Find centre as midpoint of diameter}\\[0.5em]
    \text{Radius }&=\sqrt{(3-(-1))^2+(-1-2)^2}=\sqrt{25}=5&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Calculate radius using distance formula}\\[1em]
    &\hspace{1.5cm}(x-3)^2+(y+1)^2=25&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Substitute into equation and simplify}
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}

## The General Equation of the Circle

\vspace{-0.5cm}

The equation of the circle with centre $(3,-4)$ and radius $7$ can be expanded:

\vspace{-0.7cm}

\begin{align*}
    (x-3)^2+(y+4)^2&=49\\[0.5em]
    (x^2-6x+9)+(y^2+8y+16)&=49\\[0.5em]
    x^2+y^2-6x+8y+9+16-49&=0\\[0.5em]
    x^2+y^2-6x+8y-24&=0
\end{align*}

\vspace{-0.5cm}

This expanded form is called the \textcolor{MidnightBlue}{\textbf{general equation of the circle}}.

\vspace{-0.3cm}

\begin{center}
\begin{tcolorbox}[colback=red!5,colframe=red!70!black]
\centering
\textbf{General Equation of the Circle} \textit{(as provided on the formula sheet)}:
\begin{equation*}
    \text{The circle with centre }(-g,-f)\text{ and radius }\sqrt{g^2+f^2-c}\text{ has equation:}
\end{equation*}
\vspace{-0.6cm}
\begin{equation*}
    x^2+y^2+2gx+2fy+c=0
\end{equation*}

\end{tcolorbox}
\end{center}

\vspace{-0.3cm}

Unless specified, there is no requirement to expand the equation of the circle into the general form.

It is necessary, however, to be able to determine the radius and centre of a circle given its general equation.

By equating $x$ and $y$ coefficients, and constant terms, the radius and centre can be found:

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example,colback=MidnightBlue!1, colframe=MidnightBlue]

A circle has equation $x^2+y^2+14x-12y+9=0$. Determine its centre and radius.

\tcblower

\vspace{-0.5cm}

\begin{align*}
    x^2+y^2+2gx+2fy+c&=0&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Write down general equation in }g,f,c\\[0.5em]
    x^2+y^2+14x-12y+9&=0&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Align equation of circle given}\\[1em]
    g=7\hspace{0.5cm}f=-6\hspace{0.5cm}c=9&&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Find the values of }g,f,c\\[1em]
    \text{centre}&=(-g,-f)&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Find centre}\\[0.5em]
    &=(-7,-(-6))&&\\[0.5em]
    &=(-7,6)&&\\[1em]
    \text{radius}&=\sqrt{g^2+f^2-c}&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Find radius}\\[0.5em]
    &=\sqrt{7^2+(-6)^2-9}&&\\[0.5em]
    &=\sqrt{49+36-9}&&\\[0.5em]
    &=\sqrt{76}&&\\[0.5em]
    &=2\sqrt{19}&&
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}

Note that the equation $x^2+y^2+2gx+2fy+c=0$ only defines a circle where $g^2+f^2-c>0$.

## The Intersection of a Line and a Circle

\vspace{-0.5cm}

Given a circle and a line lying on the $x$-$y$ Cartesian plane, one of three possible relationships must apply:

\vspace{-0.5cm}

\begin{multicols}{3}

\begin{center}
    \begin{tikzpicture}
        \draw[white] (-3,-2.2) rectangle (3,2.5);
        \node[below,text width=5.5cm,MidnightBlue,align=center] at (0,2.5) {the line and circle intersect at two points};
        \draw[thick] (0,0) circle (1.2cm);
        \draw[thick] (-85:1.4) -- ++(60:2.4);
        \draw[MidnightBlue,fill] (0.25,-1.174) circle (0.06);
        \draw[MidnightBlue,fill] (1.14,0.37) circle (0.06);
        \node[below,MidnightBlue] at (0,-1.5) {$b^2-4ac>0$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

\begin{center}
    \begin{tikzpicture}
        \draw[white] (-3,-2.2) rectangle (3,2.5);
        \node[below,text width=5.5cm,MidnightBlue,align=center] at (0,2.5) {the line meets the circle at a tangent};
        \draw[thick] (0,0) circle (1.2cm);
        \draw[thick] (-30:1.2) -- ++(60:1.2) --++(-120:2.4);
        \draw[MidnightBlue,fill] (-30:1.2) circle (0.06);
        \node[below,MidnightBlue] at (0,-1.5) {$b^2-4ac=0$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

\begin{center}
    \begin{tikzpicture}
        \draw[white] (-3,-2.2) rectangle (3,2.5);
        \node[below,text width=5.5cm,MidnightBlue,align=center] at (0,2.5) {the line does not intersect the circle};
        \draw[thick] (0,0) circle (1.2cm);
        \draw[thick] (-60:1.6) -- ++(60:2.4);
        \node[below,MidnightBlue] at (0,-1.5) {$b^2-4ac<0$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

\end{multicols}

\vspace{-0.5cm}

Whether seeking to *find points of intersection*, *find the point of contact for a tangent*, or *show that the line and circle do not intersect*, the process should begin with preparing to solve simultaneous equations. Since the equation of a circle does not lend itself to being written in the form "$y=\dots$", solving simultaneous equations to find points of intersection between a line and a circle will require the \textcolor{MidnightBlue}{\textbf{substitution method}}.

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example,colback=MidnightBlue!1, colframe=MidnightBlue]

Show that the line with the equation $y\ -x=-7$ is a tangent to the circle with the equation $x^{2}+y^{2}-4x+2y-3=0$, and find the point of contact.

\tcblower

\vspace{-0.5cm}

\begin{align*}
    y&=x-7&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Prepare the equation of the line for substitution}\\[0.5em]
    x^2+/color{MidnightBlue}(x-7)/color{black}^2-4x+2/color{}(x-7)/color{}-3&=0&&\color{MidnightBlue}\longleftarrow \text{Substitute into the equation of the circle}\\[1em]
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}
